fields.title: add codeblock input widget
fields.description: I'd like to be able to add codeblocks as either comments or uploads or part of ticket description -- something like that. Something that lets users suggest code and let other users see it. Maybe even the option for syntax highlighting and selecting what language.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/topics/class-based-views/generic-display/#dynamic-filtering

```python
def test():
	pass
```

Used simplemde (simple markdown editor) as a javascript-based editor for the forms. Used python-markdown for the codeblock rendering.

fields.title: Ticket closing button
fields.description: Add a button to ticket details page to close a ticket. Require confirmation popup.
fields.resolution:
Two main pieces: I updated views.py to include a TicketDetailsResolution view. This is a form view that updates the ticket resolution and the ticket status.

I also had to update the SuperTicketDetails view to differentiate between two different POST requests. This required updating the HTML form with names for the submit buttons. Then, in SuperTicketDetails, I look for those names in request.POST and serve up the corresponding form view.

Also created a new form for ticket updating which only has the resolution field. This is the form that gets served up in the TicketDetailsResolution view.

Finally, the core HTML: added a bootstrap modal that contains the form.

fields.title: Add field to tickets to describe how it was resolved
fields.description: Need to see if adding a field to a model causes problems. Should be able to fill out this field in the closing ticket popup dialog.
fields.resolution: Added a resolution field to the model and a markdown editor for the update ticket page. Resolution is also displayed on the ticket details page if the resolution exists.

fields.title: Remove spellchecker highlighting from SMDE
fields.resolution: added `spellChecker: false;` to the SimpleMDE instantiation.

fields.title: Archiving projects
fields.description: Need to be able to archive projects, like closing tickets.
fields.resolution: Added ArchiveProject view, did it the Django way, from the docs. Might still need some cleanup though.

fields.title: Reopen tickets
fields.description: Need to be able to reopen tickets.
fields.resolution:
Created a new view: TicketReopen, which is a form view with a form_valid and form_invalid methods that both change ticket status and save. Feels kind of clunky, but it works. Not sure if it's best practices.

I don't really know how to handle empty forms, or make database changes without sending a form. Need to ask Craig.

fields.title: Change TicketReopen view to be like ArchiveProject view
fields.description: The way I'm currently doing it is all messed up. Fix, please.
fields.resolution: removed FormView subclassing, just subclassed View instead, handled the logic in the post() method, bypassed form_valid() and form_invalid() entirely.

fields.title: Change ticket resolution form to be like ArchiveProject form
fields.description: This one will be much trickier. But I think I can use the generic Form view to bypass form_valid and form_invalid, which I believe is where the problem is. Will have to change the HTML from a bootstrap_form injection into a generic textarea input widget. Then we can just grab the text with request.method.GET.get('name') or whatever.
fields.resolution: Didn't do anything like the description. The problem was in the relevant Form class. I had set the resolution model attribute to blank=True, but I didn't set the field in the Form class to required=False, so even though the attribute wasn't required by the model, it was required by the form, hence the form was coming back invalid when it was left blank. Fixing that solved the issue, and I was able to remove all the overwrites of the form_invalid() method.

fields.title: Remove spellchecker from all SMDE
fields.resolution: Pretty sure I got them all. If any are missing, just need to add `{spellChecker: false,}` to the function call to `SimpleMDE()`.

fields.title: Assign developers to projects
fields.description:
I'd like for managers to be able to view all the tickets assigned to each developer on their projects, so that they can see everyone's workload. Dynamic queryset filtering seems like the best method. See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/topics/class-based-views/generic-display/#dynamic-filtering

Update: changing the scope of this a little bit. I want developers to be assigned to projects and then only able to view the projects to which they are assigned and the tickets associated with those projects.
fields.resolution:
Did a sweeping revision of how permissions work. Created two permission mixins called `ViewProjectMixin` and `ViewTicketMixin`. They both check the project (or, for the ticket mixin, the project to which the ticket is assigned) and see if the user is either the project's manager or in the list of assigned developers. If not, permission denied. All project and ticket views now have this mixin incorporated.

Also added a staff only mixin to project creation.

The only edge case so far is for ticket submission. Since tickets don't have related projects until they're created, I needed a way to prevent users from submitting tickets to projects they aren't assigned to. So I modified the get() method on the CreateTicket view. It now grabs the pk from the URL kwargs and gets the project associated with that pk. It then checks if the user is either the manager of that project, one of the project's developers, or staff. If not, raise PermissionDenied. Then I removed the project selection from the creation form and had the project assigned during form validation using the same logic (getting the project based on the URL kwarg).

fields.title: Allow blank description

fields.title: Add Team Leader role
fields.description:
If I'm going to have users able to log into this, they can't all be admin, obviously. So I'll need to add a team leader role which lets people do some of the things that are currently restricted to admin. Right now, the main one is creating new projects. That needs to be something only a team leader can do. Though maybe multiple team leaders makes more sense.

Also, user management. Inviting users to a team. That part is going to be much harder than I thought.

https://github.com/bee-keeper/django-invitations https://django-organizations.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started.html
https://simpleisbetterthancomplex.com/tutorial/2016/07/28/how-to-create-django-signals.html https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57207796/how-to-associate-invited-users-with-the-inviters-company-group https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61936580/modifying-the-django-invitations-package-to-allow-team-functionality

# From Craig:
I highly recommend delaying actual integration with an email provider Django has a concept of email_backends which provide pluggable email service And one of them is the console_backend that simply prints email contents to the stdout (aka, the terminal running manage.py runserver) And that's plenty good enough to start. You can copy the URLs from those printed emails and pretend you're the new user in an incognito window Once it's time to actually integrate with email, I'd probably go with Mailgun, but it's a medium-grade headache that you don't strictly need to move forward

My next recommendation there: encode everything in the URLs A common pattern might be to generate random UIDs for teams and include that in the invite link You can safely assume no one will guess a different team's UID, so it's a time when "security by obscurity" is actually acceptable So an invite email might contain a link to thewebsite.com/team-invites/abcd-efgh-1234-4567-restofuid And abcd-... was auto-generated for that team when it was inserted into the database Oh and also encode the user, obviously So it could be /team-invites/?team=&user= There are 1 trillion acceptable ways to do it, so don't feel trapped to go with that implementation
fields.resolution: Team leader (owner) role is essentially done. Owner has ability to create projects. Also added team invitation functionality. Will create separate, more detailed tickets for that though.

Added a `filter_for_team_and_user` filter to `Project` and `Ticket` querysets, since those two factors interact now. Updated the `Project` create and update views to work with a new `ProjectForm`, which filters the `manager` field to those users who are managers for the given team. Also updated the project filter selection to only show team-level managers in the dropdown. Really added a lot of functionality here.

fields.title: Can add non-team members as managers by manual URL edits
fields.description: Users can currently add non-team-members as managers by manually editing the add manager url config. Need to add validation to that view such that it first checks if the user being added as a manager is a team member.
fields.resolution:
Added a simple check in the view.
```py
if user not in team.members.all():
            raise Http404("Cannot make a user who is not a team member into a manager.")
```

fields.title: Implement select_related() and prefetch_related() method for querysets
fields.description:
I have lots of querysets that span relationships. Can see the template tags that look something like `{{ ticket.developers.all }}` or something. This code hits the database to find the developers. Instead, I need to rewrite my querysets using select_related(), like so: `queryset = Ticket.objects.all().select_related('developer')` and so on.

Many-to-many and many-to-one relationships have to use `prefetch_related()` instead.

See the docs for implementation: [select related and prefetch related](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/ref/models/querysets/#select-related)
Also see 14.3.3 in 2 Scoops.
fields.resolution: Added methods mainly for user, developer, and manager related fields in the ListViews. Didn't see many other places to implement.

fields.title: Add filter/search to the ticket table in project details view
fields.resolution: Modified the `get_table_data()` method for the view to first check for a `q` URL query string. If so, returns `super().get_table_data().filter(title__icontains=q)`. Added a reset button as well.

fields.title: Team invite capability
fields.description:
Need ability to invite people to team.

This comprises two parts:

The accepting invite process. This is already done, with the AcceptTeamInvitation view.

The inviting process: a view where team owners can input an email address to create a new invitation. This view should also handle sending the email to the email address provided, which will contain a link to the AcceptTeamInvitation view with the invitation UUID.
fields.resolution: Team owners can now send email to invite users to teams. They can enter a username in the case of an existing user or an email address for an existing or non-existing user. The email includes a link to the invite. The logic is in the SendTeamInvitation view and the TeamInvitation model itself, where the email is formatted and sent.

fields.title: Git Integration
fields.description: It would be interesting to have an optional connection between a git branch and a ticket. Have any pull requests or commits or whatever else get posted as comments on that ticket with links to the changes.

fields.title: Change admin URL
fields.description: Want to customize it to something other than /admin/ so that attackers can't just guess.

fields.title: User model ForeignKey best practices
fields.description: Django recommends using settings.AUTH_USER_MODEL or whatever it's called for ForeignKey relations to User. See 2 scoops 22.1.1. Not sure if I can do it in the middle of a project though. Will have to check.

fields.title: Subscribe to ticket to receive emails when new comments posted
fields.description: Should subscribe by default for ticket submitters. Could also have a project-level subscription, where you receive emails for every comment on any ticket. And a subscription management page.
fields.resolution:
Added three categories of views: subscribing, unsubscribing, and managing/viewing subscriptions.

For subscribing: added an individual subscription view with a link on the ticket details page. Added a link in project details page to subscribe to all tickets for a project.

For unsubscribing: same as the above, plus the ability to unsubscribe from multiple tickets at once. This is incorporated with...

For managing/viewing: a table view that shows all active subscriptions for open tickets and unarchived projects. Users can select multiple tickets from this table and unsubscribe from all of them with a button click.

As for subscriptions themselves: users receive an email whenever a ticket is closed or has a comment posted to it. These emails are only sent if the ticket is open and the project is unarchived.

fields.title: Refactor team.owner template tags
fields.description: Refactor the TeamOwnerMixin to put a value in context if the user has team owner permissions. Then, in template tags, instead of checking team.owner, can just check for this context. That way, if I decide to change how team ownership works and, say, add in team administrators that have all the same powers as a team owner, I can just update the TeamOwnerMixin to give those users the context variable as well, and I won't have to update every single template tag.

fields.title: Subscribe to all tickets doesn't sub to new tickets
fields.description: Users who subscribe to all tickets of a project likely expect to be subscribed to new tickets as they are created. So that means I'll probably need a project-level subscription flag. Will also need to figure out the post_save() or post_create() or something like that. Or maybe overwrite save to have it save twice? Once to assign ID and then again to assign subscribers? Not sure I can do that though. Creating a linktable for subscriptions seems cleaner. Might as well have users auto-subscribe to tickets they make once I get that done too.

fields.title: Subscribe to project (new tickets, all tickets)
fields.description: Need to be able to subscribe to projects and get emails when new tickets are posted. Also connected to ideas in the subscribe to all tickets idea.

fields.title: Email users when added as team/project developers/managers
Create a linktable subscription model
fields.description:
Something like this.
```py
class TicketSubscription(models.Model):
	ticket = models.ForeignKey(models.Ticket)
	user = models.ForeignKey(settings.AUTH_USER_MODEL)
```
Really that simple. Then can query those models to do subscription things.

fields.title: Team membership model refactor
fields.description:
Might need to refactor to make a team membership model. Would be a huge refactor, but probably for the best.
```py
class TeamMembership(models.Model):
	team = models.ForeignKey(Team)
	user = models.ForeignKey(User)
	role = models.IntegerField(choices=ROLE_CHOICES)
```
Something like that.

fields.text:
```python
def hey_listen():
	print("Comments also have markdown!")
```
This seems like a good jumping off point: [creating a manager with QuerySet methods](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/topics/db/managers/#creating-a-manager-with-queryset-methods)
See ticket about adding a team leader role. It will be necessary to implement this.

Made some serious progress. Added teams, linked them to users, projects, and tickets. Added a filter_for_team() method to object querysets. Then reworked the URLs. That was the big part. Now all URLs pull from a default context supplied by a CommonContextMixin that grabs url kwargs. It's complicated. Still need to test that everything works, and then need to totally rework the homepage. But we're getting there.
Pretty sure I did. Will check later.

I think I've got the best of both worlds. Just have a manager flag, no developer flag. So users are developers by default but have to be flagged as managers before they can do manager things. Lets me filter the manager dropdowns as I want and remove a lot of user headache.
It has a get_full_name accessor on it, but that method doesn't exist anymore. Easy fix.

Craig's suggestion: don't bother checking the currently viewed project against the recently viewed on. Just add an attribute to the user model and update it with the URL every time the user visits a page.

My version of the idea: grab the project pk with my CommonTemplateContextMixin (if it exists). Save that number to the User attribute. Then can grab the project from that pk for the link on the homepage.

From Craig:
```py
class Invitation(models.Model):
    user = models.FK(User, default=None, null=True, blank=True)
    email = models.CharField(...)
    key = models.CharField(help_text='Used in invitation URLs')
    teams = models.ManyToManyField(help_text='Teams this user is invited to. When a user is created from this invitation, we create one Membership record per team.')

class Membership(models.Model):

    PENDING = 1
    ACCEPTED = 2
    DECLINED = 3

    STATUSES = (
        (PENDING, 'Pending',),
        (ACCEPTED, 'Accepted',),
        (DECLINED, 'Declined',),
    )

    user = models.FK(User)
    team = models.FK(Team)
    status = models.IntegerField(choices=STATUSES)
```
I think I would start with those pseudo-models
So in the above, the inviter types the email to which the invitation will be delivered
The user clicks the link which is points to thewebsite.com/invitations/<invitation_key>/ and signs up
They pick whatever username and email they want, and that user is created
A reference to said user is stored on the original Invitation record
And then their Invitation.teams values are turned into Membership records
(also, this is all just how I would handle it -- you really should NOT feel like it's a sin to stick with your implementation)
You can then also add the following to your Team model:
```py
members = models.ManyToManyField(User, through=Membership, related_name='teams')
```
